133999006,english,I'm only 9.6 hours into the game and I have so much left to discover. This world is full of adventure!,2023-03-03 21:31:19,True,0,0,True,False,False,14,2,2091,2091,575,2023-03-07 02:06:21

I wanted to be objective on this review so I left it for some while and waited for my excitement to go down. Fromsoftware and their games are my favourites. I love Souls-Borne series the most of all games.
I started with Dark Souls 2 and after it played through Dark Souls 3, Bloodborne, Sekiro. DS1 and Demon Souls I saw on the live stream.

Then I played an absurd amount of souls-like games from other studios or indie developers, for example: Surge 1+2, Hellpoint, Lords of the Fallen, Nioh 1+2, Ashen, Mortal Shell, Salt and Sanctuary, Code Vein, Thymesia, Death's Gambit etc.
The point is I love the souls like formula in the games and all these games that I mentioned are great but I wanted something fresh, because all of these game follows the same pattern.
When Elden Ring was first announced I thought of it as no big deal, but man was I wrong.

Elden Ring took the souls formula and pushed it to another level - open world. It could sound terrifying but it isn't, trust me. The masters from Fromsoftware did absolutely amazing job in implementing all that we like into an open world. The world is full of activities, enemies, bosses, items (every one item except consumables has its own specific place), NPCs and stories and full of amazing lore that we love. The game challenges you at every corner and I thought not even once that I'm bored. Worlds on Ubisoft ""checklist"" basis are nothing compared to the world of Elden Ring.

Build variety is as amazing, maybe better than in Dark Souls. Main dungeons are sweet and complex locations like in the previous games. Side dungeons are okey, sometimes they look similar to each other, but it depend on ""biome"" in which you currently are. There are lot of secret tombs and theres questline for witch Ranni, that opens a whole area of the map that you cannot find otherway. Skills, spells, weapons feel epic and adds a lot of flavour to your playthrough.
It's a fresh wind for souls games and I hope the coming DLC would be even better than the main storyline.
+ Graphics are slightly better but nothing big, so I felt like home from the beggining
+ Epic bosses, even better than in previous games (I mean main bosses)
- It's not ideal for a newbies to souls games
For me Elden Ring is 10/10 game, that will have a place in my heart for eternity.",2023-03-03 20:19:53,True,0,0,True,False,False,232,6,12276,0,12276,2022-04-30 15:26:07

133994370,english,"Had some stuttering issues at launch, and it's still not the most optimized title From has ever put out, but that's to be expected of Japanese dev PC ports.

Peaks a little early in my opinion, the first half of the game feels like a true adventure with challenging difficulty and new content around every corner, but once you reach the halfway point, some of the content starts to feel a bit stale and a bit easy if you're using all the tools the game gives you.
That being said, it's a fantastic game, and probably the most complete/polished game From has ever put out.

133992838,english,"When I was in my lowest lows there was a lot of hype surrounding ELDEN RING's release, so me being a meat rider I decided to buy it, and it was the best meat riding I have ever done.

The game was pretty fun I'd say. Some highlights of my many playthroughs were Ranni, my feelings of hatred towards Commander Niall, the satisfaction of flawlessly doing a no hit run on Radagon and Immediately almost dying to the space worm god, playing space song slowed and reverb while looking at the Academy of Raya Lucaria, and most importantly putting the ring on Ranni's finger. All great times. So uh yeah.

Basically what I'm trying to say is that ELDEN RING gave me head, and it was awesome... And so my friends, with all that said can we all agree that the true ELDEN RING is the friends we made along the way?",2023-03-03 19:33:06,True,1,0,True,False,False,26,2,2902,178,2902,2023-02-28 14:25:17

133990877,english,"Even if it does violate... The Golden Order.""
These are some of the first words you will hear in Elden Ring. It plants a mystery in your mind that persists until the very end. I knew right then that this game was something beyond special.

Elden Ring is a difficult game, especially for new-comers like me, who are new to the Souls-series of games, but that did not stop my endless amazement and sense of wonder every step I took. The environments, the bosses, the silent storytelling of the world around me was so.. unique. The more I played, the more I wanted to know, and I fell deep down the rabbit hole of this game's world.
I will never forget the cinematic landscapes you see for each new area, the distant castle walls or giant golden trees. It is truly something you need to experience.

The gameplay itself is quick and tight, the bosses pose interesting challenges that respect your time. Slaying a boss, especially the ones in the main story, feels like you really did something substantial, as often the world changes around you in their absence.
You are only ever given one goal in Elden Ring that truly matters.
Become the Elden Lord, no matter the cost.",2023-03-03 18:57:25,True,3,0,False,False,False,92,12,18401,2972,17929,2023-03-06 03:03:54

133980063,english,"game is only 50 gigabyte cause they copy-pasted almost everything at least 1 time, every dungeon looks the exact same and even has the same mobs.

its nice to have alot of bosses but maybe they should have made them more interactive and make the animations as big as the hitbox. the last 2 bosses were probably the worst thing i fought in any game ever

very clunky combat system, the animation of not having pots left to drink stuns for about 3 seconds and cant be canceled. about 90 % of the time enemy hits cancel your attack and sometimes your own hits cc for 3 seconds and there seems to be no pattern, putting on 3x better gear against cc didnt make any difference either.

the game is not that bad, offers a lot of content for not too much money but if you play it keep one thing in mind: YOU CAN SKIP BOSSES. some bosses have such poor designs or hitboxes, they dont deserve to die. If you want to just run through i recommend strenght build, its about 50% better than any other build and doesnt even get outscaled in late game despite only leveling vigor and strenght

move on and feel hollow either way
Serious issues with the pacing of this game. Feel extremely under levelled the entire time

I got how the levelling is supposed to work but the time it takes to go up a single level esp if you want to use strong things that need like 30 in half the stats means you're clearly not meant to be grinding the same enemies to get there because the only farm able enemies give like 11 runes
so the only option is fight and win against whatever is the strongest thing you can find is
and half the time you have no idea if its worth it
you slam your head against this giant whatever for half an hour or more, finally get it and all it gives you is some crafting ingredient and 1k runes, what is point in trying after you get that
meaning the entire game is just getting pummelled by the next OP boss that just shits on you in 0.3 seconds

133953327,english,ELDEN RING is the best game of 2022 in my opinion I have played this game for 200 hours and still find more things to do. It is insane how much content is in this game. The combat is fluid, good and the build variety is insane.  I have not even tried all the builds in this game. The boss's are some of the best in any video game I have ever seen and are very memorable. Any gamer should give this game a shot but the only issue on PC is some fps drops in certain areas but never in boss fights it does not bother me that much. In conclusion this is a masterpiece of are generation. I am very thankful this game exists because I have never seen this much ambition to make such a wonderful game and being in fresh air as it is a different game then most AAA titles. If you don't give up on your journey through the lands of between it would be a unforgettable gaming experience.",2023-03-03 04:38:08,True,0,0,True,False,False,38,5,13916,837,13736,2023-03-05 23:30:20

133928592,english,"I bought Elden Ring shortly after it came out because I missed playing some souls-like, and man was I blown away by how beautiful and well made the game is.
And HUGE. Oh my... is the map huge. There's just always more and more and more even when you think you've seen it all.
The addition of horseback riding has definitely been a nice new thing that I know a lot of players are liking. (though I didn't really mind walking in previous games)
I also think spells are probably better and makes more sense now than they have in the past in FromSoftware games. Which is good cause I always found spellcasting to be pretty weird in their games.

The world and its colours are absolutely stunningly beautiful, the bossfights are epic and fun and you have a massive arsenal of weapons and armor to choose from, with 'Ashes of War' to add new abilities.
Overall with how well made the world is and how much effort you can feel has been put into it I would call Elden Ring a masterpiece and I'll give it like a 9.5/10

The only downside I have with the game is stuff like quests are still so vague and weird like I think they have always been in FromSoftware soulslike games which is a bit ugh for me and some of my friends. But I know it's kind of in their style at this point. It is just not very appealing in my opinion.

But you can always just focus on the main storyline in the game and you will still have plenty of stuff to do in this huge world. :)",2023-03-02 19:05:03,True,1,0,True,False,False,452,36,14351,0,14351,2022-10-28 23:45:32

133914516,english,"This is the video game that makes me love video games again. Elden Ring is everything I ever wanted in a game. It's big. It's beautiful. column2: who could ask for a better game. Just remember the only way up is down because you will die. Sometimes you won't understand why you died, other times you know why you died but can't accept it. So just go in and die. Then go back in and die again, and yes, you will die again ... and again ... and again ... until you realized that after all those deaths that you suffered through. 133904783,english,"TLDR: This is my favorite game of all time, and I think you should try it. :)
(Below includes a few details like mechanics, but does not mention any spoilers for major events, locations, or characters)

Choice in Elden Ring is abundant. The game begins with the ability to select a class, each including different armor, weapons, and starting stats. Picking any one of these DOES NOT lock you into a specific playstyle for the rest of the game, they merely give you your choice of starting gear to begin your journey. As you progress, you will be able to find and equip different armor pieces, weapons/combinations of weapons, skills that can be applied to most weapons, and spells/incantations. Despite these being the basics of defense and offense, there are many other ways you can play that include things like sneaking, a flask you can mix ingredients into that have many varying effects, craftable temporary throwing weapons, horseback combat, spirits you can summon into battle, and many more. Most importantly to me, you can use your environment to your advantage such as destroying explosives, knocking enemies off ledges, ambushing, etc. Choice may also be applied to how you finish the game, as there are multiple ending you can achieve in wildly different ways. Some of these endings are straightforward and easy to find, while others I know for a fact I would never have found if I didn't hear about them. Being an open world game, it becomes obvious that you have multiple paths that you can go at any given moment, but Elden Ring does it very well. MOST OF THIS GAME is content that isn't needed to finish the story, and there are entire locations that are hidden off the beaten path with ZERO indication of their existence.

It's no secret that this game is difficult. I have played multiple games made by this developer that are just as infamous for their difficulty, and I still had a hard time getting through it. If difficulty is something you don't enjoy, then this might not be the game for you, but I suggest you at least finish reading the rest of this segment. Difficulty in this game does not vary with an ""Easy, Medium, or Hard"" set of modes, but instead, the difficulty comes from choice and circumstance. The playstyle you choose may make some parts of the game more difficult and some more easy. I found that in order to make the game easier or harder comes purely from how you limit yourself. The multiplayer mechanics of this game can mean that you don't have to lift a finger to win this game. Doing a challenge run where you limit yourself in specific ways can make it a run that isn't humanly possible. If you feel that the game isn't hard enough, then you can subtract certain elements of the game to make it a more challenging and fulfilling game. Another thing that makes the game more difficult is after beating the game. When you finish the game, you have the choice to ""Start Journey 2"" which bring your character, armaments, level, and all, to do the story again, but the enemies hurt more and have more HP, but also drop more runes for leveling. Each cycle that you do amplifies these things up until Journey 8, which is as hard as it gets, but you can still restart the game with the same character endlessly if you wish. Benefits of starting a new journey with the same character also include trying new endings, and doing/getting things in case you missed them last time. But if you want the game to be easier for you, you have multiple options. You can summon up to 2 players at a time to aid you or use spirit summons in areas they're allowed. You can also go somewhere else to grind for levels so that you stand a better chance in an area. You can even look up enemy weaknesses if you'd like, as there is a massive community for this game that has knowledge about it all.

There are multiple ways to interact with other players within the game. The first thing to note is that there aren't other players simply walking around in this open world, but instead, you see messages and bloodstains. The messages are written by other players using a small list of words. These messages can be helpful, funny, pointless, or deceitful, but generally it's a good idea to read them on your journey. Bloodstains can be interacted with to show a red phantom of another player's last moments before death, which can show you how dangerous an area is. White phantoms can sometimes be seen phasing in and out of your world. These phantoms are other players as they simply play the game, and they're a nice reminder that others are doing just as you're doing. Summon signs can be placed down so that you can be summoned into another world to help another player. Up to 2 players can be summoned by the host at once, and once at least one has been summoned, your world can be open for invasion. An invasion is when a player uses an item to search for worlds to invade so they can kill the host. Red summon signs can be placed to to bring another player into your world so you can fight them. If you want a fair pvp experience, there are 3 colosseums throughout the land that have their own sets of rules to play by or choose from. Lastly, if you are invaded, you can use an item to call for help so you have an ally summoned to rid the invader.
No matter how you want to play this game, the right way is the way YOU choose.
- How the design affects the gameplay -

Elden Ring has a massive amount design elements that merge amazingly with the gameplay. The developers of this game are known for environmental storytelling. By surveying your environment, you can get insight into the story of the game, or know if an area is dangerous. But many of the design elements of the game can influence a player's decisions. I suggest that you pay attention to your environment as you travel. :)

If the visual elements don't make a good enough of an environment for you, I found the ambiance to be perfect for every area I visited. The songs are elaborate and beautiful, and fit each situation very well. I haven't had a single issue with audio choice.

If you're a fan of lore, I have fantastic news for you. There are pieces of lore in just about every corner of the game. Weapon descriptions that give crucial detail on a specific character or location, the architecture implying the origins of a place, enemies being in specific places.
I have always been a fan of titles like The Elder Scrolls, Destiny 2, Call of Duty, PokÃ©mon, Dark Souls and such
column2: games that give you an abundance of choice so you can play however you wish. Elden Ring to me is the best game I have ever played. The care put into it is immense, and I consider it a masterpiece. I can see myself playing it for years to come, trying new things or reliving the experience. Subjectively, it's a 10 out of 10 for me, because the shortcomings pale in comparison to the strengths, and that's how I think. Objectively, there is no such thing as a perfect game. There will always be imperfections and issues a game will have, but I can see Elden Ring as being one of the top games of this decade.

column1: Regardless of what games mean to you, I suggest that you try it out for yourself to see if it's for you or not. Generally, if you like open world, challenge, choice, multiplayer, and stunning graphics, I would say it's likely you'll enjoy Elden Ring. Issues that I saw from myself or other friends that played the game, it's a pretty demanding game when it comes to your PC specs. Often times a friend of mine would have FPS issues and needed to turn the graphics down a bunch, and it ended up looking pretty rough. Although lag is an issue in every pvp experience, it was especially frustrating to me in Elden Ring because much of the core gameplay revolves around timing your inputs, and any delay is a big difference.",2023-03-02 09:29:23,True,0,0,True,False,False,57,1,21925,199,21925,2023-03-02 03:15:16

133902722,english,"I always found the Souls games to be a bit inaccessible, but Elden Ring was the first time I really ""got"" what is special about the genre and about From Software.

The unique world, with lore as deep as you care to delve, full of brilliant design and art direction, makes Elden Ring stand out as uniquely enticing among a sea of same-y open world games. There are no quest arrows or compasses, and minimal hand-holding in general
column2: a refreshing harkening back to a time when RPGs didn't focus on being streamlined as much as they did on being immersive. Everything has an exciting air of mystery. You have to explore in Elden Ring, and it doesn't feel like a chore or a distraction or a time sink standing in the way of getting to the good stuff. None of the content here feels like filler. (The vast majority of it is optional, in fact. Side quests are not afterthoughts, they're the core of the experience.) Exploration is rewarding here. It's what you'll want to do as you play, and the game's design philosophy is all about encouraging it, letting the player mostly direct their own journey.

column1: Combat can be difficult, yes, but also rewarding and deep, offering tons of build options where most things feel viable and nothing feels particularly obligatory. Most of what turned me off about the souls-like genre before, was not wanting to reach a sticking point and becoming frustrated with my inability to advance. Elden Ring is full of challenging bosses that you may bang your head against, but the open and non-linear nature of the game means you always have some other content you can go do instead if you get stuck on a particular encounter. Leveling up and finding better gear is basically always an option. Elden Ring challenges, and can sometimes frustrate, but never quite enough to keep you away. And the feeling of accomplishment when you are successful is all the sweeter.

It's clear when you play that for the game's creators, this was a labor of love. It's not perfect, but what flaws it has are easy to overlook in face of it's many virtues. If you're like me and you're apprehensive about it because of the Souls genre's reputation for difficulty and high skill floor, do yourself a favor and take the chance on this one. You may surprise yourself, and this game will probably surprise you.

I want to like this game. I really REALLY want to like this game.

Becuase the first 1/2-2/3 of this game is good! Very fun, lots of enemy variety and exploring every nook and cranny is a fun and rewarding experience! The bosses for the most part were a great time to smash my head against.

And then i got to the Atlus plains and the game became a boring irritating slog. Almost instantly too. The bosses become repeats of bosses you've already seen, the basic enemies are the exact same as the enemies that you've seen for the last 4 areas, just tankier and hit harder. The game feels like they front loaded it with all of the exciting content then desperately had to fill in the rest of the game with copy and pasted content.

It managed to retroactively dislike previous boss fights by having the exact same boss show up again, and im not talking about some random enemy demon or tree, im talking about storied named bosses that you beat and then they just randomly show up again. There are roughly 10 bosses that you have to fight only once. Out of 170.
It is honestly one of the most frustrating games i've played in where the first 2/3 are really really fun and then you run into a steel wall of disappointment and frustration.
Honestly is worse than Dark souls 1 and 3.",2023-03-02 06:54:40,False,5,0,True,False,False,249,12,8805,2615,8805,2023-03-02 06:40:31

133900483,english,All of the things of this game is amazing. But the true reason i bought this is because of the wide amount of player information and jokes held inside. (even if it does get old sometimes). Unlike some of the other games i have or want. this game is leagues above in both stunning video quality and audio. the audio in this game is unlike any other with each boss seemingly having their own ""theme"" and even some regions having their own genre. such as the stormveil castle sounding completely different than Raya Lucaria showing the inventors brilliance and self inflicting torture of attempting to make a good game greater Reliant on nothing except the backgrounds. Honestly, if you do get this game for a few minutes just listen to the ambient sound, the birds chirping the horses clopping, the strange dog man hiding as a tree, and the random sound of a huge ass arrow being shot at you from 50 miles away. For me at least simply the visual(until you see some of the bosses!) and auditory features of this game make it worth the 60 dollars completely worth it.",2023-03-02 06:53:32,True,0,0,True,False,False,8,2,794,794,630,2023-03-05 06:27:21
133900454,english,"A souls-like rpg that over-delivers what it promised.

- The gearing system is great, seeing the way your character changes during the journey, and wielding stronger armaments. Even though there are many tier lists, you are fine with any weapons as long as you enjoy them.
- The huge map makes it easy to miss out on some of the optional bosses, so make sure you explore every corner.
- The lore is great, but you have to watch some videos to better understand it.

This is the first time I'm playing a souls-like game and after my first playthrough, I can easily say that this is one of the best games I have ever played if it's not the best.",2023-03-02 06:52:13,True,1,0,True,False,False,41,1,6528,6528,5242,2023-03-05 20:56:38

133900359,english,"After sekiro this was my next from soft souls-like game. Sekiro as a first time experience in this genre was tough. took me years of on and off playing to beat it. But this... I dont know if I would call it a game even. Its more than that. I think I can say that what FromSoft does is well passed extraordinary. Its changed my view on how I like, view and experience video games. And i've been playing games since i was 5 (am now 1 month away from being 24).

You know how people say ""oh it grew on me"" this does that but it doesn't stop growing on you. We're all curious naturally being human beings its in our DNA, our blood to explore and try. There's endless amounts of that in this game. The only thing that has more to offer, in that area of exploration and curiosity, is life itself. And as odd as that may sound for me to say talking about a video game. its true.

I might be a little off the wire becuase its 12:45am and I've just come off of a grueling 14 hour shift. nonetheless, if you thought about playing this game and can afford it then you should buy it and play it. But in your own way and in your own time.

133899881,english,"Elden Ring is a game that isn't even too ridiculously difficult, it's just kinda... boring. You don't get any progression until like... thirty hours into the game, and if you want to put that time into it, great, but it's just too hard to get into for me. I wouldn't recommend unless you are prepared to G R I N D. not worth the money imo.",2023-03-02 06:31:56,False,3,0,True,False,False,94,14,225,0,225,2023-01-19 21:43:57
133899388,english,"Feels more like Assassin's Creed than Dark Souls.

Side-questing is a must or you'll be under-leveled, which is incredibly tedious in such a MASSIVE game. Most bosses and areas are just copy pasted versions of early game content which gives the game a samey feel. Really easy to make busted and cheesy builds, more fun to blast past the game the cheap way which, is overall a letdown for me despite how entertaining and rich the experience can be.",2023-03-02 06:15:58,True,0,0,True,False,False,226,8,11183,2750,10533,2023-03-07 07:32:53

133892273,english,"First souls game for me.  I hated it.  Put it down for several months.  Decided to try it again because a buddy of mine kept playing it.  But during those several months, I was grinding the crap out of monster hunter world which I believe helped me understand the mechanics of Elden Ring.  You're grinding a lot, you want to build your character as much as you can in order to die less and in order to defeat the boss.  A game that i once hated but now I love because you realize how flexible this game is.  You play the game how you want to play it
column2: you set the difficulty how you want to set it.  There are so many ways to play the game and i believe that is how a game should be.  On top of that, a very beautiful game.  Give this game a shot, be patient with it and it will give you the tools you need (literally like spirits to help you tank for example) if you choose to use it to enjoy the game throughout.  It's no wonder it won game of the year.  I've yet to beat the game and I've put in 180 hours already.  it's that big to get yourself lost in and have fun with it.",2023-03-02 02:50:32,True,0,0,True,False,False,82,1,11544,3289,10842,2023-03-07 06:06:49

133889932,english,"I was very on the fence about giving this a thumbs up. I am a  fond owner of most of FromSoftwares work even own an old copy of King's Field running around here somewhere. I feel like this is an awesome game in the skin of a Souls project. The open world is refreshing, the story is better told in a way to understand whats going on and you have some idea of where to go but often find yourself wondering whats around the bend. The combat for me is a slippery slope. The combat while fun and engaging fall short of feeling fair due to the balance of enemies HP pools you often feel like even basic enemies can be spongy and bosses are giant sponges and this really threw me off from enjoying the game thoroughly. Unless you lookup a build that breaking the game in some way, there isn't a great way to nab a regular weapon and feel okay going about your play without wanting to pull out your hair. Even though I don't care for the tanky HP I still feel like this game is the proper evolution of the souls franchise and can't wait to see what else comes out FromSoftware.",2023-03-02 01:45:43,True,0,0,True,False,False,229,32,2835,73,2835,2023-02-28 06:04:31

133882336,english,"After 136 hours with every second containing so much amazement, I have finally accidentally beaten the game.  More specifically, gotten a different ending than I'd liked. [spoiler](Don't tell the wife!)[/spoiler]

Elden Ring is the grandest souls game to date, with so much content that had me in complete awe from the second I started playing to the second I ended my playthrough.  The devs truely outshone the competition with this one, and it's going to be hard to compete in the future!

The only disappointment is that it had ended, but as the saying goes, ""It is better to be happy that it happened rather than sad that it is over"".  At least until the dlc comes out (hopefully) soon!",2023-03-01 22:35:02,True,0,0,True,False,False,372,7,8935,634,8808,2023-03-03 22:46:37

column2: I'm extremely disappointed. The obvious flaws of previous DS games is present once again (jank movement, enemies swinging through the same walls you bounce off of... the list goes on) but NOW there's even more jank! You have tedious ass platforming on a swivel stick goat, you have scaling bosses negating any sort of leaving, getting stronger, and coming back... you have no inspiration to explore because the boss you're stuck on will be just as (if not more) difficult when you return.

column1: There are BROKEN npcs in this game. Example: There's a singing harpie in the lake that does piss all damage to you. You can sit still and solo him and the entirety of his guards.
Unless. Unless he uses one move that AUTOMATICALLY HITS (it actually puts your character into an animation at it's start that becomes uncontrollable) and one shots you.
A random, singing, low level harpie. Has piss all stats but contains a ONE HIT KILL.
And there are a LOT of these scenarios. Balancing doesn't exist in this game.

The movement issues and fighting problems could be EASILY identified by even 10 hours of play test from one human, so I'm beyond sure they're aware and just throw it into the ""Difficulty is fun regardless of design"" basket they love to bank on.
The game is a slap in the face. It takes away the core concepts of an ARPG, but keeps the difficulty of pretentious level movement.

And the pausing. Holy ever loving fuck, the ability for enemies to slow down one of their attacks at random in a string of nromally quick attacks. What the fuck? It's not something WE can do so why would you have to contest with it?

This game amounts to 100+ hours of jank deaths then RnG'ing through moves used into a victory that honestly... feels hollow as fuck by the end. I don't feel as if I mastered their moveset and could destroy them at any time now that I have
column2: I just feel that one of their moves didn't AUTO KO me and I happened to pull a win. I don't feel like I put the work in to get stronger to surpass it, I feel as if it's the same fight as before I went and leveled. Once again negating my effort.

column1: I'm sorry but. Not sorry. This game needs a massive overhaul to become enjoyable. Right now the only people sucking this game off are diehard souls fans who believe that FromSoftware can do no fucking wrong.
But. It can. And does. 1995 PS1 titles had better programmed clipping ffs."" - DragonfruitCapable
The real reviews are on reddit. And theyre accurate save your money.

133879927,english,"Coming from someone who's played through every Souls game multiple time, plus Bloodborne/Sekiro, with Bloodborne being my favourite, this game is such a let down! They've essentially taken Dark Souls 3 and slapped it into an open-world.

My biggest gripe with the game is they've seemingly made the game hard just for the sake of being hard. It seems like most enemies, especially bosses, are all running at Bloodborne speed (with 360 gymnastics, jumping all over the place, infinite stamina, spamming combos, crazy damage) while the player character is running at Dark Souls 1 speed. Gone is the challenging yet fair game-play of their previous games.

My second gripe is the open-world aspect. It's so boring! There's not enough in it to actually explore, so you're essentially just running from one major area to another, with a few bits and pieces in between. The atmosphere and the look of the world is great though.
Elden Ring would've benefited so much more from proper interconnected world design.
Nearly everything else is also just copy pasted from previous games, the combat, the animations etc.

I'd say if this is your first From Software game, you may enjoy it, but, I would suggest you play Dark Souls 1 and/or Bloodborne instead.",2023-03-01 21:44:26,False,3,0,False,False,False,792,8,1518,1518,1518,2023-03-01 19:24:28

Once you have some levels, a set build, and weapon upgrades it comes down to learning the fights and how to outplay bosses. Super fun and amazing time! 133875065,english,"The game is fun for the first 20 hours, afterwards its just an average open world game. I don't know if I will end up finishing the game because every enemy I fight drains more and more joy out of this game. I have no clue what is happening story wise by the way. 133873710,english,"As expected, great game all around, not short of a masterpiece. However, it is not without its issues. The combat is great, but could be better designed borrowing some elements from its predecessors (as sekiro, for exemple) there is such a thing as greatly designed difficulty and poorly designed difficulty. This game stands in the middle. In conclusion
column2: the combat is good and memorable but with some issues that start to become too clear in NG+. The PvP is suffering from same balence issues in the current moment (patch 1.08 -one of the clear issues is the new patched light roll, its is such a safe mechanic that a stalemate can be forcefully dragged the end of the match by just dodging as stated by some experienced streamers)). But I hope the devs will tackle those problems in balence patches later on. 133864626,english,"Despite the open-world singleplayer RPG genre continually devolving into pointless fetch quests, poorly written dialogue, and excessive hand-holding, Elden Ring stands out by doing everything exactly how other games don't - and it works beautifully.

This is essentially my first Souls game. I very briefly played DS3, and barely played Sekiro, so I began Elden Ring with an open mind and virtually no expectations. I assumed I'd be in for an interesting, combat centric pseudo-RPG that would be confusing and frustrating.

That's what I got, however for some reason, despite initial frustrations with difficulty, the overload of information that is the stats screen, and the complete lack of guidance in what to do, Elden Ring is absurdly captivating. The environments are varied and gorgeous, dungeons are clearly crafted with care and attention to detail, and characters are interesting (lovable sort ahead).

This is the first game that has had me absolutely and entirely immersed since some of my all-time favourite single-player experiences such as Fallout: New Vegas or Skyrim. The Lands Between is an expanse packed to the brim with fun content, interesting loot, and once you start exploring you never want to stop. The questlines are interesting (though you'll definitely need some help from Fextralife), and the boss fights are straight up epic. The music is downright beautiful and the visuals are so unique, so stylized, and so gorgeous in so many different ways.

I have tried to write and rewrite this review for months, and every time, I feel dissatisfied with my own ability to convey exactly how much this game has blown me away. But now, I think I've found the perfect way to put it:

I put down Elden Ring after playing non-stop, clocking almost 300 hours. Wanting to scratch my open world RPG itch, I revisited Witcher 3 and put in a cool 70 hours then put it down for a reason I couldn't understand. So I put together a new Skyrim modlist, spent probably 30 hours modding and troubleshooting and then another 30 playing, then put it down for a reason I couldn't understand. Hogwarts Legacy came out, and despite my love for the Harry Potter universe, for some reason I couldn't even push myself to finish the main story. I finally relented, and came to terms with the fact that I'd just rather be playing this game.

Elden Ring is a masterpiece. It is an undeniable champion amongst a stale genre saturated with mediocrity and tired franchises. It is a tour de force, a chef d'ouvre, a piÃ¨ce de rÃ©sistance. Yes, I pulled up a thesaurus.

133854579,english,"NOTE: I played this game at launch.
This review will compare Elden Ring to Dark Souls III a lot for obvious reasons.

The open world formula hurts this game a lot. A sense of bewilderment is common when you move around with barely any direction at all. You get indications to sites of grace, but that's it. When i tried going someplace interesting on my own i got stomped instantly. If i didn't explore the crevices of the vast empty land, i was under leveled. If i explored everything then i saw the same ruins asset and enemies scattered everywhere. It felt like a grind and exploration for the sake of exploration.

When i moved on to the ""correct"" path, and there certainly is one, although the game nor the players tell you that, it all felt very good. The pacing was amazing. This harkens back to my previous statement
column2: when the developer guides you in and puts you through the curated experience (i.e you play it like Dark Souls 3), it's really, really good. When you actually do open world content, it actually kind of sucks.

column1: A huge flaw in design for me is the way they introduce you this danger. Spoilers: There is a point in the game where you get transported from the starting zone, to a much higher level Zone, Caelid. It's very obvious you are supposed to, and should, run. So i did. I got to a site of grace and went back home. This is introduced if you enter an obscure cave with a chest at the end. The run where i didn't do this, and entered as i normally would with Torrent, i got stomped by the enemies and lost my runes.

Therefore, it's apparent to me that the game is made to be explored and scoured for treasure. However, this content is repetitive. The same reused caves and bosses are littered across the map and give you cool stuff. The enemies here are annoying and the same in all of them, with varying layouts. Completing these is mostly a chore you do to unlock things. Not once did i do a dungeon and find it a refreshing or interesting experience. Oh, and if you skip all these you will likely be under leveled and miss out on all the cool stuff.

Following the curated experience is good. I wish they had taken more steps to gently guide you in game instead so they could lean into what they do best, the ""dancing"" with the bosses. Dark Souls 3 had exquisite combat flow and each boss had a built-in rythm to learn, with few exceptions (looking at you, Oceiros). The satisfaction from completely dismantling a boss by learning their every move was amazing. It truly felt like you rose from the ashes and became stronger by learning every time. The bosses in Elden Ring attack you so mercilessly that you offload some hits to your summons instead or just abuse magic so you avoid the combat.  The openings you gain are therefore the boss attacking your meatshield instead of your own skill dodging their attacks and abusing these openings, especially if you use heavy weapons.
I repeat, the intended way to play the game is by not interacting with the boss.
To see the anthisesis of this, and my ideal version of the game, look at the Iudex Gundyr or Dragonslayer Armor fight from Dark Souls 3.

To summarize, I feel the design around summons and the bosses are poorly done. Removing summons in boss fights, if not altogether, would drastically improve the game. There is no option to not use summons unless you want to use exploits, metagame or otherwise play OP builds, and not what you find fun.
The weapons and ashes of war are good. The combat is better with more variation and more moves to learn. The progression is there.

column2: DR The game is okay, but ultimately dissapointing coming from Dark Souls 3. Two steps forward in some directions, two steps back in others.",2023-03-01 12:40:25,False,3,0,False,False,False,159,6,4302,0,4302,2022-04-06 23:47:30

133844637,english,"I have to say, Elden Ring is easily one of the best games I've played in recent years. The world is absolutely stunning, and the level of detail that has gone into creating it is truly impressive. I found myself constantly getting lost in the game's vast open world, always discovering new areas and secrets.

The combat mechanics are also top-notch, as expected from a FromSoftware game. Every enemy encounter felt like a challenging and rewarding experience, and the boss battles were some of the most epic and intense I've ever played in a video game.

But what really sets Elden Ring apart is its storytelling. George R.R. Martin's involvement has clearly had a significant impact, as the game's world and lore are rich and deep, with plenty of twists and turns that kept me hooked throughout.

Overall, Elden Ring is a masterpiece of a game that truly deserves all the hype it has received. It's a must-play for any fan of action RPGs or FromSoftware's previous titles. I can't wait to dive back into the game and uncover even more of its secrets.",2023-03-01 07:12:19,True,1,0,True,False,False,408,6,7192,0,7192,2022-08-14 04:02:36

133841927,english,"It's a friggin' souls game. If you're into them, you already know whats good. Strangely enough, I actually had a hard time getting into it. Since I've played the souls games since Demon's, I learned that the games have so much hidden.... EVERYTHING that it's easy to miss stuff. Alright, just to start off, I truly believe this game is fantastic. But to truly appreciate it, you have to go in with the right mindset. Oftentimes it seems like people hop into this game to prove something to themselves or others and then have their fragile egos shattered when the game proves to be a bit of a challenge. This was sort of how I went into the game. A buddy of mine who was a bit of a Souls veteran decided to brag a bit about beating the Tree Sentinel (first field boss you come across) at base level (they chose Vagabond, I think). So I thought to myself, ""I'd like to do that too"". And if you've never played a Souls game (me), it's a bit of a humbling experience. However, your persistence WILL pay off. My first time beating the Tree Sentinel took probably more than 40 tries. My successful run was about 20 minutes long and I felt great since I beat him with a Level 1 Wretch. Now, I've learned to beat him in under 3 minutes. That's the thing, you just get better. When you can keep your appreciation for the game above your ego, you can have hours upon hours of fun while watching yourself become better at the game. I'm currently about to reach 500 hours as I'm typing this. Still having a blast with the whole thing. That being said, there are some definite pros and cons to the game which I'll list:

-[b]Mouse and Keyboard controls.[/b] Honestly, I played through the entire game with mouse and keyboard. It wasn't horrible, but it was quite frustrating. From what I've heard, it's a constant FromSoftware issue. The games are supposedly just meant to be played on controller. I had a constant issue trying to do charged heavy attacks. Any time I'd hold down the heavy attack button, I would be locked into a light attack immediately after. I eventually managed to fix this by uncapping my frames with a mod, but we shouldn't have to risk getting banned to enjoy the game properly.

-[b]60 FPS cap.[/b] Last I checked, the game is still locked in 60 FPS. It plays very smoothly, but if you have anything over an RTX 3060, you probably want to see what Elden Ring can do. So I ended up playing the rest of the game at 170 FPS and 140% FOV using a mod. Was silky smooth after that.

-[b]Multiplayer limitations.[/b] So, if you're expecting to just hop into the game and play the whole thing with your friends, guess again. FromSoftware decided that you need to craft an item every time you want to play with a friend. On top of that, you lose access to your horse, summons, ability to traverse freely, sitting at graces, and from what I've seen, the ability to parry. It's just not a fun experience at all. However, there is a Co-op mod which fixes all of those things and is quite fun to play with. Invaders absolutely hate it, but nobody cares what they think anyway so mod it up. Just remember to disable EAC. v:

-[b]Awkward quest management.[/b] So, unless you're following along to an online guide, there's a pretty high possibility that you're going to progress passed a quest and potentially lock yourself out of content because of it. This then forces you to either make a new character, reload your save (assuming you're aware of how to do that), or go into New Game+. It makes for a unique first playthrough, but it is a tad annoying when you realize all the cool stuff you missed the first time around.
-[b][i]Some[/i] limited fashion options.[/b] Not really an issue, but you might struggle to find some decent armor combinations. I know I personally did, but I'm pretty picky.

-[b]It's a complete game.[/b] You're not going to find any areas where it seemed that the devs were cutting corners. You could maybe make a point about some repeat bosses, but all in all, nothing seems unfinished. Some people had some glitchiness when the game first came out, but I didn't have a single issue aside from anything I've said above. Honestly, these last few years, we've sort of grown accustomed to the consistent theme of game developers who just want to release a product and fix it over the game's life cycle. ([i]*cough* Call of Duty *cough*[/i]) That's just not a problem here. FromSoftware had an idea and they saw it through to the very end.

-[b]Amazing design.[/b] It's not hard to get caught in awe while looking around in this game. It's insane to think that a group of people got together and made this. From the boss design to the environments to the animations to the UI elements, it's just beautiful. There are some funky looking things here and there, but you can look up the lore behind them and your appreciation for them increases tenfold.

-[b]Replayability.[/b] There are so many different builds you can run in this game. You wanna run a Bleed build? Level your Arcane and get a quick weapon like a twinblade or dual katanas. Want to just go around slicing things with a big sword? Well, there are plenty of big swords in this game. Two-handing a weapon goes a long way, applying a 50% increase to your Strength stat. Like magic? You can choose between Sorcery or Incantations, both with their own respective stats and equipment scaling. Or, if you're really hardcore, go around with a naked Level 1 Wretch and bonk things with your club. That'll teach Malenia.

-[b]Good confidence builder.[/b] A lot of people insist that this is one of the easiest Souls games. Whether that is true or not, the fact of the matter is, the game is difficult. If you can beat Malenia, that's something to be proud of. Most people uninstall at Margit. So beating this game is something you can consider an actual achievement. Not to say it's a rare occurrence, but it's a long shot from the straight forward goals of many other games.

column2: DR[/h1]

133830629,english,"I've been an avid action rpg player since I was a kid, starting with Phantasy Star Online on the Dreamcast.  In 2022 and 2023 I played a lot of Splatoon 3, Monster Hunter Rise, and am more recently Playing Risk of Rain 2, Valheim, and Deep Rock Galactic.  All of these games I listed have superb combat and very fitting combat.  They feel good, they're fun, and I find all of these games to control in an enjoyable way.  By that, I mean that they have excellent gameplay.
Elden Ring's gameplay feel and loop are very poor.  The controls and gameplay itself have offered me the least fun that I have ever had in an action rpg game.

Now, before you begin harassing me in claims that I just don't like ""difficult"" games, I found that Elden Ring is one of the least punishing action rpgs I have ever played.  If you are spending your runes, as you should, then death in this game is literally not a problem at all and there is no reason to fear dying.  So punishing is definitely not a term I would use. ""Difficult"" is somewhat of a subjective term, but what I am assuming players mean by ""difficult"" in this context is not ""difficult"", but actually tedious.
You really only have about 3 things that you might do:

One is to dodge, dodge, dodge, and of course to dodge again and again.  The main gameplay loop is to continually dodge poor optimized, in terms of time, attacks.  The key to not getting hit is to time your dodge, but if you play this game or watch gameplay, there are so many times when you expect to get hit but don't or expect not to get hit but do.  Ultimately, this leads to nothing more than spamming the dodge button like a madman as a go around to this issue.  And that ultimately leads to boring gameplay.

The second thing you might do is attack.  Attacks are done on a controller using the R1 and R2 triggers.  The R2 trigger gives you a kind of charge attack or a slower but heavier hit.  However, as we talked about timing issues, R2 is just far too impractical to even bother using with a basic melee weapon.  It is better to get your poke in with an R1 then run, or rather, to continue your dodge-athon.  Which leads me into explaining why this is so terribly boring.  You are spending most time avoiding combat and being disengaged for one, but more importantly, there isn't a lot of action coming from the player, or combos, or effects that might compromise the opponent, or disable them, or lead to giving the player some kind of advantage due to their fight strategy and so forth.  The action part of the action combat is the player running and evading a barrage of attacks or projectiles from an enemy combatant.  Sure there are spells and you can summon pets or something to spice things up, but if you want to play, or rather, engage in combat, your access to participate in the process of action within this ACTION rpg are incredibly limited.

The third main thing that might comprise your gameplay is using items, which would be a bomb, or a heal potion, or mana potion, whatever you are carrying with you.  These potions are your main source of healing or mana rejuvenation and you will be using them a lot to continue your combat participation.  However, there is a very very big problem with this system.  You want to make sure that you have the item you may need to use on the fly as your selected item because you do not want to have to change active items during combat, as the joystick that controls your sprite is separate from the joystick to change items, which would be your d-pad.  Now, strategically this adds excitement into what would be otherwise very boring gameplay, due to the strategy of selecting items before engaging or running away so you can switch to your mana potion to continue casting spells, or whatever, but the real problem here is that you are literally taking control off of your character in order to access your items.  The switching of items requires a letting go of control of your character and creates a back and forth of engagement and disengagement.  Monster Hunter does this too with their item system, but in the case of Monster Hunter it has very little effect on your ability to continue engagement in the battle.  You can wire bug and dive back in.  In Elden Ring you dodge like a madman, get far far away, then switch items or heal or whatever, then dodge dodge your way back in.  It's simply tedious and boring and this is because your sprite completely lacks mobility.  And,  Monster Hunter does not make you feel like you are giving up control of your character to access items.
In sum, there are better games out there.  The popularity of this game just goes to show that it is not quality that people desire but to be a part of the popular.

The best I could give this game is a 7/10 and even that 7 seems overly generous.  The combat is boring, does not feel rewarding, makes you feel gimped and weak (not in a positive way), discourages engagement, and is severely lacking in complexity or technique.  Defeating an enemy gives you no satisfaction due to anything you have done and simply leaves you with an empty feeling of relief.  I would not recommend this game to anyone.

ELDEN RING is what I always hoped and dreamed modern gaming would become. I am a huge DARK SOULS franchise fan and I would also declare this one easily the objective best one yet through the sheer hours of content at your fingertips.

You are tarnished. A forgotten and unimportant soul who is maidenless. Luckily you meet Melina who is willing to guide you through your journey as your personal maiden / waifu. She gives you the reins to a spiritual beast named Torrent and your objective it to defeat the Shardbearers and ultimately become Elden Lord through one of the various ways of doing so.

ELDEN RING is insane because it's a 2022 released game that is superior to all of it's predecessors and does not feature any kind of cheapness or monetization whatsoever. It's really a breath of fresh air and every waking moment spent playing this game is true peak escapism and entertainment factor. Featuring beautiful visuals and a way larger than necessary / expected world to explore. I've always liked the SOULS franchises' NPCs but this game takes it a step further in elaborating and explaining each and every character not to mention how cool they look and how they all stand out from each other.

The bosses are the reason to play these games and whether FromSoftware realised that or just decided to go with an open world filled with seemingly endless bosses isn't actually important. The fact the player has a map, a steed, and fast travel from the get go between Sites of Grace make the quality of life so good for veterans of the series who just want to ride past everything, enjoy the scenery, and defeat some legendarily high quality bosses. Many people claim this is the easiest SOULS game but they are definitely wrong since there are some bosses in this game that are far more difficult than anything we've ever previously encountered
column2: the hardest bosses from past games were Orphan of Kos & Darkeater Midir, and those two do not even compare to the likes of someone like Malenia, Blade of Miquella in this game who is borderline impossible to do solo no matter how good you are. The world and it's levels are obviously easier then past games and I prefer it this way actually
column3: because it rewards thorough exploration and gives the player the ability to choose how much of a challenge they actually want since they can seek out more powerful weapons and Ashes if they want, and get early upgrade materials that will out-scale the majority of the game, or you can simply follow the linear path and go from story required boss to story required boss in a straight line without enhancing your character too much which will prove much more challenging.

column1: ELDEN RING is a one of a kind game and shows us how far FromSoftware has come from the cash grabby low effort days of something like DARK SOULS II. There will be nothing like this ever again I assume and if you only play one video game for the rest of your life, choose this one.

133827616,english,I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.",2023-02-28 23:27:12,True,1,0,True,False,False,60,4,5501,788,5310,2023-03-04 23:26:22

133824796,english,Great game. Doesn't give you much in terms of knowing where and what to do, but it is very rewarding once you do",2023-02-28 22:26:30,True,2,0,True,False,False,8,1,6467,122,6467,2023-02-28 22:06:46
You are are revived and you find yourself in the Lands Between. Embarking on an epic quest you will need to find and to do what it takes to become and Elden Lord.

The visuals, sound and music are stunning. The world building is great: there are so many locations to explore, so many secrets to discover and the monster design never gets boring. And then when you have thought you saw everything you are thrown in another big adventure. There are optional areas in the game that you may just walk by because you don't realize they are there. There are bosses and mini-bosses that you will not see unless you look for them. It brings you back to how games used to be: explore and find new things without everything being served on a plate to you. Being able to complete the game and then realize the game wasn't serving you all the content but instead you need to discover it is great.

The multiplayer portion is similar to Death Stranding where other players can leave you messages and you can see little blood spots where other players died. It's also cool to see the ghosts of others moving through the world and of course you can PvP if you want if you have the correct items. It's a good thing to fully integrate this in the game as prevent you from feeling lonely. There is some PVE and PVP and with the right items equipped you can select what you would like to do.

The items and equipment that you can find is absolutely amazing: even more when you realize that there are no DLCs, microtransactions or other schemes. You pay what you get and it works. I wish other games were still like that.

The difficulty can be punishing at times - it's part of the charm of the game / series but you might get frustrated because you feel it's unfair. You will need to build your character and get to understand the game mechanics or the bosses will make quick work of you. Without the right tactics you will die a lot regardless whether you are a high level or not. It can be frustrating but all it means you are not good enough - level up, practise, get better and rethink your tactics :-).
You will need to use a gamepad to play this game. I cannot see how you can play this with mouse and keyboard. I used a Switch Pro Controller and that worked great.

While not experiencing bugs or system issues I got several disconnects from the multiplayer part because of ""Inappropriate Activity Detected, Unable to Start in Online Mode"". I have no idea what happened here as I was just riding my horse at those times. Usually after 10 - 15 minutes I was able to logging back on.

There are many extended quests in the game. You will not realize this at first as there is no quest book, tracker or even on-screen notification. As you can kill NPCs you may lose their story lines without even realizing it.

You will have to make choices but there is not really a good or bad one so it's much how you want to role play. Because of this system as you may like to explore a lot you will find that quests have moved on: NPCs moved to a different location than you expected or you just don't realize there was a quest at all. This can be a bit annoying at times especially when you have play sessions every few days. It's hard to get back on track without making lots of notes.

The marker system on the map only allows 100 bookmarks but there are so many more areas to explore. I wish the limit was raised as in the end I had to keep track of my progress in a notepad. Very much how I used to play old style games.
Why can't we turn off chromatic aberration? I know there is a mod but I didn't want to play my first play through using a mod.
Your character cannot swim or climb I loved that in Zelda Breath of the Wild or Assassin's Creed and I wish we could do it here as well.

There are many, many systems in the game that you find or miss. Basically, you can upgrade just about everything but you need to find the right location, NPC and items. The game will do little to hold your hand it's up to you to discover.

I enjoyed my journey through the Lands Between so far and I will definitely return. It was tough at times but it felt like a breath of fresh air. The visuals and audio are some of the best, I have ever seen. The world building is amazing and I enjoyed all the secrets that I found but also that I learned there is even more to find. Hopefully other developers will study what Elden Ring does well and learn from it as it sets a new milestone for open world gaming.",2023-02-28 22:16:44,True,0,0,False,False,False,387,61,7256,0,7256,2022-11-22 19:09:09
133824103,english,Greatest game ever made. I've said all I wanted.,2023-02-28 22:12:12,True,0,0,False,False,False,38,5,10855,0,10855,2023-01-04 20:00:30

133823994,english,"I want to love this game so bad. The exploration and world building is only next to a game like outer wilds. Just wandering around this world feels so great and fills me with so much wonder and it baffles me to think all this land with rich history was forged by a game studio. Coming over a hill to see more land after I though I'd reached the edge of the map and the excitement that I get filled with is literally incredible. But that excitement is immediately thwarted by a large sigh and disappointment when I see a boss that's going to be tedious and frustrating to fight.
This is why I know I can't love this game because the bosses in the game are just not fun to fight and there's over 100 of them spread over every inch of this beautiful map.

The bosses are just tedious and feel more like I'm supposed to put more hours into leveling up than practicing to beat them. A large majority of the bosses contain move-sets and combos that can last up to 20 seconds only leaving the player to get in a measly hit which does a sliver of damage. So the player has to hope that within this insane, unreadable dance of attacks they don't get hit lest they die and then barely make a dent in the boss's health...Then repeat over and over again and then you have a large majority of the boss fights in this game. This form of combat feels less like a duel between worthy adversaries and more a like a toddler against Mike Tyson. Its just so tedious and doesn't leave the player satisfied for beating a challenging foe but instead leaves them exhausted and glad they don't have to do that fight again.

I do recommend this game though. Its like actually insane how fantastic this open world experience is. I just think its unfortunate its bogged down by the horrendous and tedious boss combat. I don't think Elden Ring is a masterpiece by any means but its definitely the best concept game I've ever played. If FromSoftware can make another game of this same scope and open world combined with lets say the combat of Sekiro, my god would that be the game of my dreams. But unfortunately the combat drags down one of the best open worlds I've explored.",2023-02-28 22:09:58,True,0,0,True,False,False,109,1,3383,962,3080,2023-03-04 08:37:21

133818727,english,"I thought ""time for suffering"" so I bought this, and then behold, strong foe! Then this really shady role-playing ""maiden"" comes along - conveniently right after this other fella called me maidenless - and she's like ""Erdtree, and then seek Elden Ring"". Okay, will do!

Next thing I know, I'm trying fingers and everything bloody else I can scavenge because imps keep stealing my runes. ""Try parrying"" you might be thinking, well I'm trying but the noob in me hasn't packed his things and moved out just yet. Nobody I'd met thus far felt it worthwhile to mention all the death ahead, and then death ahead, but death ahead it is. If death was a currency I'd be the Jeff Bezos of the Lands Between, I tell ya.
Stay calm, seek strength"" I said to myself as I dragged my demolished ass through Brazil after some vapelord decided to play a hilarious prank gone wrong, and that was only the beginning!
Boy, is this an experience. Gorgeous view, dog, Bill Clinton, sweet man-made horrors beyond my comprehension... could this be the game of all time?

Because it's time. It's Mohgwyn time. And I intend to mohg all over that Sekiro reject - I didn't catch her name - who likes to dance with waterfowl or whatever.",2023-02-28 20:32:41,True,0,0,True,False,False,1,1,23623,4399,21866,2023-03-06 23:27:44

133804528,english,"I've never liked the Dark Souls series since I'm no masochist nor do I hate myself. Although the combat is very much the same I find it less clunky and no stamina consumption outside of combat is cool.

This game really pulls weight for those who like to wander and not be tied down to linearity. For every discovery lies a challenge and something valuable or insightful behind it. The grand scale of the well designed world brings up a lot of questions and consequently drives one to find answers which gets you more drawn into the game. I find the community is also better than DS. This is a game meant to be played with a 2nd monitor to pull up guides and general info.
Argue all you want, you won't fool me to thinking dork souls is better",2023-02-28 16:01:26,True,0,0,False,False,False,276,14,13784,480,13784,2023-02-26 19:33:48

133803849,english,After finishing a slow playthrough, throughout last year I would return to elden ring when I just wanted to exist in the lands between. The combat feels the best of all the souls-like games, the world is gorgeous, and all the bosses are anime as fuck! If this is your first souls game, this is definitely the game to play, as they have really streamlined a ""choose your own difficulty"" mechanics. Spells are more varied and magic is less intimidating to play at the start, spirit summons can make a lot of bosses way easier, and it is easier than ever to get summoned help. Use your mount if you can! Torrent is amazing, I've never played a game before where I felt the power of calvary, horses op, but in a good way.
I think Elden Ring has taken Bloodborne's place as my favorite souls-borne game, and I can't wait for the DLC!",2023-02-28 15:48:38,True,0,0,True,False,False,85,2,12204,479,12036,2023-03-04 19:14:55

133799653,english,"What an absolute masterpiece of a game. Definitely deserved GOTY.

I have never played souls-like game before and I was very skeptical. In the beginning you are thrown in a massive world with little to no guidance and everything is written inside description notes found deep in your inventory. I, ofcourse, didn't knew about it and was banging my head around to find any useful information if possible.
Getting killed many times by Agheel Lake Dragon and eventually entering the trap inside ruins behind it xDD (I am pretty sure everyone suffered from it). Game felt unforgiving right from the start.

But, this is where open-word and true freedom started showing it's charm. I could just smack some dude and see if I am remotely capable of defeating them or not. Roaming around and going to depths as well as far away corners started paying off little by little. Although I was very slow at levelling up in the beginning (level 44 after 45 hours) but atleast I could explore at my own pace.
Took little bit help from ""Elden Ring Discord Server"" (very nice people) and kept going ahead. Beautiful locations and nicely optimized game were added bonus.

After a while, story and progression started to make sense and I could piece together progress map to move ahead and this is where the game began to look much more enjoyable. It almost took me 55 hours to fall in love with Elden Ring and realise it's GOTY awards. Completed lots of side quests and defeated almost every boss except (2 evergoals and dragon placidusax). Some bosses felt punishing even after learning so much and they gave true satisfaction upon defeating them.
Gametime - 100 hours (if a noob like me took 130 hours, I am pretty sure average player will take a lot less)

133794962,english,"I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 12 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he let me borrow his controller. Me and my son then played in turns and I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.",2023-02-28 12:33:03,True,6,0,True,False,False,60,7,9,0,9,2023-01-05 06:36:49

133788894,english,"(Note that all of my play sessions were exclusively with the seamless co-op mod because yay co-op and screw invasions and EAC.)

It's the dream. An open world Dark Souls game. What's not to love? Shame it lost game of the year to Bill Clinton. So many ways to play and it's fairly noob friendly while still chewing you up and spitting you out like a Souls game should. I can't beat bosses naked with a ham sandwitch like some people, but once you find a build and figure things out, it's godly. Iv'e got a Sephiroth rivers of blood thing going on for my main character and it's great.

If you love co-op and hate PVP like me, grab the Seamless co-op mod from Nexus Mods. It uses Steam servers and a .ini password instead of Fromsoft's servers, a separate executable and bypasses the need for Epic's performance sapping spyware known as EAC. Make sure you get your steed and your summon bell before starting because you may miss them during co-op, but it's 100% full time co-op without the usual Souls summoning signs and boss restrictions. It's glorious fun. Watching your friend get yeeted off a cliff by a pumpkin head never stops being funny.

133783172,english,Planning to get at least level 731 in this game. Supper fun,2023-02-28 06:19:37,True,0,0,True,False,False,107,7,6897,5919,5609,2023-03-07 06:06:02
133782612,english,"Elden Ring won Game of the Year, makes sense, its a great game.

Souls-Borne games usually aren't accessible to newer players, but this one certainly was. Over 120+ hours in, and I'm still being amazed by this. Don't think it might be too late to play this game, cause FromSoft still hasn't released a DLC. But with everything good, there is always bad.....

Jesus, From really needs to stop making random ""poison"" lakes, or in this one, the forsaken Lake of Rot. Go get Flame Cleanse me, and honestly to be true, it wouldn't be a souls game without one bad area. Actually that's not the only Hell you are going to go through. It's nice that they outsourced to religious figures, because the Subterranean-Shunning Grounds were made by Satan. Now I see myself as a idiot, but when we got to the very funny troll parkour that would lead to the Three Fingers, it made me so happy. I was constantly trying to not hurl myself off the Golden Gate Bridge, and honestly please FromSoft, it was very funny in the end when I figured out that I just had to ""Git Gud"" like everyone else was telling me. But one more hell....... MALENIA!!!!! I'm gonna say the truth, many guides online told me stuff, but ultimately, just why. It's a GOD-DAMN SEKIRO BOSS??? Man this is one middle-finger to every From enjoyer, because along with no Bloodborne PC Port after 7 F****** Years, we also get given a boss from Sekiro, which didn't get a DLC.

Lore is always an iffy subject in From-Soft games, because we have Youtubers that finish the job George R. R. Martin couldn't. The Only Thing I Know For Real though is that we should not have to figure out this sh** ourselves, and ultimately, my head hurts after trying to figure out why the worst bosses (Foreskin Duo) is repeated at least 3 times (separately or not). I get it, its a large game, you are gonna have to re-use bosses, but please. Godefroy (Godrick reskin) Two Godfrey and Loretta boss battles, and the same for Mohg and Margit (Not counting Morgott). At least Placidusax was cool. Would cry myself to sleep again over trying to figure out why I still suck at the game.

Even after all the hatred written in this message for some parts, 10/10 game, would uninstall and go pull maidens IRL if I could, unfortunately this game probably stole all my rizz. Anyway please, anyone else wants a Bloodborne PC port? From please, I'm on my knees, begging, just give us the port........ maybe within this century??? (Please I will be happy)",2023-02-28 06:03:43,True,0,0,True,False,False,16,5,9536,2547,8298,2023-03-07 01:45:20

133778146,english,Probably one of the best games I've ever played. Despite filling me with so much rage, I'll never get back the experience I got playing this for the first time in its entirety. I don't think a single game in history had gotten as much hype as Elden Ring pre and post-release, and it's super nice to see that people are still exploring and making Elden Ring content.",2023-02-28 03:57:45,True,0,0,True,False,False,30,6,12453,0,12453,2023-02-01 23:30:52
133778123,english,"I only recommend this game for it's adventure
column2: exploration and beauty is unparalleled and cannot match any other soulslike.

column1: However, it's combat is simultaneously a repeat of old soulslikes but done in the worst way possible. The beauty of the soulslike combat system was one-on-one combat: attack, dodge, and parry. Keeping perfect time and rhythm. This game doesn't have rhythm or timing. Just constant barrages of attacks from every single enemy barring the largest and most awkward. You will feel under pressure every second but never a chance to retaliate except for only in the most minute openings.

From Software's games have certainly felt the pressure of being ""Difficult"" and are being pressed to take it's formula and press it to it's logical maxima until it no longer resembles the original. These enemies and bosses do not feel like they are from the original or from any soulslike that has come out since, but enemies from non soulslike games. Games where the player should be able to return with equal force, but never can because they feel like they themselves are ripped from DS1.

This game will never reach the infamy of DS2 but so many encounters encompass what made that game more frustrating than fun: ambushes and memorization. Great hard games test reaction times not memorization, like the difference between the first and second Halo Legendary campaigns: where the second involved little reaction and plenty of memory after first failing many many times, the first always presented you with tests of skill for things you've previously gone through, clearly presenting the danger up front and allowing thought for your next moves for every encounter. The first Halo respected the player and wanted them to win, it understood it was a game and while it challenged the player it did not provide a wall that required narrow windows and laugh at you for not finding them. Elden Ring feels like the Dungeon Master that hated their players, the teacher that wanted you to fail, or the backstabbing friend that never was on your side.

If this was not a game then I would recommend it beyond exploring, if learning software engineering was a game I wouldn't recommend it, if learning art was a game I wouldn't recommend it, if being alive was a game I wouldn't recommend it. It doesn't matter how hard the anything is, you will eventually get good enough at to beat it. When people complain about souls games, they're not having fun. Its not because it's hard.

column2: DR/Bottom Line: The game is only kind of fun, but if every hobby, and almost every other game bores you, then you may find this game thoroughly fun after the exploration runs out.",2023-02-28 03:57:17,True,0,0,True,False,False,410,40,1189,1189,1132,2023-02-28 23:17:48

game absolutely tanks towards the end and is very front heavy, absolute masterpiece early to midgame. by the time you get to endgame there are very few new bosses (majority either reskins of earlier ones or 2 earlier ones combined into a duo that dont mesh together at all, the game gets a lot more linear with less interesting places to just come across and the balancing even at the recommended level is just not good.

10/10 until caelid where it gradually drops until eventually landing on a 7.
dont bother finishing it just play until leyndell and start a new save.

133768679,english,"A truly fantastic open world Fromsoft game. With almost no cutscenes, the game manages to tell a fantastic narrative by placing items, enemies, NPCs, designs, and the landscape itself in areas that have importance to their locations.
